review.title: Toward a Motor Theory of Sign Language Perception
review.abstract: Researches on signed languages still strongly dissociate lin- guistic issues related on phonological and phonetic aspects, and gesture studies for recognition and synthesis purposes. This paper focuses on the imbrication of motion and meaning for the analysis, synthesis and evaluation of sign language gestures. We discuss the relevance and interest of a motor theory of perception in sign language communication. According to this theory, we consider that linguistic knowledge is mapped on sensory-motor processes, and propose a methodology based on the principle of a synthesis-by-analysis approach, guided by an evaluation process that aims to validate some hypothesis and concepts of this theory. Examples from existing studies illustrate the di erent concepts and provide avenues for future work.

metadata.title: Toward a Motor Theory of Sign Language Perception

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The ever-increasing use of gestures in advanced technologies, such as augmented or virtual reality environments, calls for an increasing understanding of the various levels of gesture representation, from meanings to movements characterized by causal physical and biological phenomena, all the more so for skilled and expressive gestures such as sign gestures, both of which involve a high degree of semiotic and cognitive representation and require extreme speed, precision and physical engagement with the environment. In this paper, we emphasize the close link between the high level and low representations involved in sign languages. Signed languages are fully formed languages that serve as means of communication between deaf people. They are characterized by meanings: they have their own rules for compositional elements, grammatical structures and prospective representations that include multimodal components set into action by movements.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: This work promotes a motor theory of sign language perception as a guideline for understanding the linguistic encoding and decoding of sign language gestures. According to this theory, what we perceive is nothing other than the movement of the articulators of the body. In other words, this assumption states that linguistic knowledge is mapped to sensory-motor processes. Such a a priori statement is based on two main hypotheses: First, we are able to derive motor data from sensory data through a sensory-motor inversion process, and second, elements of linguistic information are somehow encoded into motor programs. A methodology directly derived from these two hypotheses is based on a so-called analysis-through-synthesis loop, which loop, through a perceptible evaluation of sign language by sign language experts, allows to validate or validate the hypotheses of linguistic language for codification.
